comment._content: Google Street view - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+... . I thought the "Hero of Waterloo' looks a bit plain nowadays. It has lost stonework from the top and those horizontal bands over the years. I wonder why. It now looks almost 'bauhaus'.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The note about tram wires might help date this photo too.  Trams started in August 1901 on Lower Fort Street route behind the photographer.  See discussion here - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2532463449/]

Also there are several contemporary photos of Windmill Street in State Records NSW (search for "Windmill Street'), which chronicle the impending demolition of the far left side of the street.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2633076600/]
The picture above (reverse direction) shows the Will Daley Election poster (July 1901) and the tram paraphernalia.  And two of the houses are already demolished as in the Waterloo picture.  Which implies they are contemporary at about August 1901.  But the shadows and  the slop bins are different, and who plays cricket in the winter ?!

My opinion is this photo is August / September 1901, like many of the dated photos of The Rocks.  Also I think the photographer is John Degotardi Jnr, from the excellent composition, amazing perspectives, and clarity of light.

Now to find a matching artwork . . .

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Street/backyard cricket is a year round pastime :)  
I think it's great that as well as getting a date for a photograph, all the comments paint a picture of the place and times. I can't help feeling a little sadness about the demolition of all those houses in The Rocks....

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: I love this photo ... we used the City of Sydney Archives' version of this image in the exhibition 'Sydney's pubs' at the Justice & Police Museum. You can see it here at: www3.photosau.com/cos1/scripts/home.asp One of the things I love about it is that there are two largely unknown hotels in the image in addition to the Hero, which I've identified in the notes above: The Hit or Miss Hotel (no69), next to the Stevens Buildings. There was supposedly a pub on the site from about 1819 until 1923 and was run by the Stevens' family for almost the entire time (yep the same ones that built the apartment block next door). The other was the Shipwrights arms, which was a pub apparently for only a few years in the 1830s. The original sign on the facade was uncovered in recent years during renovations. CoSA date the image to c1910 and thought it was possibly taken by Milton Kent, who took many of the resumption images for the Sydney Council around this time. But I'm leaning toward beachcomberaustralia's assessment of the date & photographer when you look at the images above and similar images from the glass plate negatives in the PHM.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: An earlier view looking the other way, taken from near the wall where the road divides, with a Boer War contingent marching down Pottinger Street: Australian War Memorial. Note no Stevens Buildings. John Henry Harvey (undated): State Library of VIC. And if you want to zoom right into the far distance to the end of Windmill Street ... State Records NSW

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Hentsch Bond Store is a useful landmark for dating many of the Millers Point and Lavender Bay photos, apart from losing two floors and getting wider in 1903. It was built in 1891 and opened in April 1892 as reported in the SMH 26/4/1892 p.3 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13842550 . The building was designed by McCredie's, of the cleansing operation fame, and originally planned to expand over the Lord Nelson Hotel site, which it surrounded. The up-to-date fire precautions described were evidently sadly inadequate.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: This photo was recently determined to be part of the Rocks Resumption photographic survey, the title and date of the image has been changed accordingly Here is a map of the Rocks Resumption area (last one in the sequence) AB
